title: Video of exploding iPhone surfaces amid growing battery safety concerns
text:
Video of exploding iPhone surfaces amid growing battery safety concerns Richard McLeish twitter TWEET More 
The explosive week in the tech world continues as a video has emerged on social media that purportedly shows an Apple iPhone 6 Plus exploding in a user's hand. 
The CCTV footage, taken on Monday at a mobile phone repair store in regional Queensland, purportedly shows what begins as a normal exchange between a customer and staff member. CCTV captures the moment an iPhone catches fire when its owner brings it to a repair shop in Queensland. 
When demonstrating the problem with his broken iPhone, the customer and his friend appear to recoil in shock as the device lets off clouds of smoke, forcing him to throw it onto the counter. 
"He considers himself extremely lucky," says Simon Owen, owner of the store who spoke to Fairfax about the incident. Related Content Woman's headphones explode on Beijing to Melbourne flight 
"It's 100 per cent pure coincidence that it happened when he was talking to the repairer. 
"Imagine if he was driving down the highway at the time. Our service counter has a giant hole in it." Advertisement 
The video appears to show the iPhone as damaged when the user applied a "standard amount of pressure" to the cracked screen to apparently demonstrate its faulty status, according to Mr Owen. 
This is not the first time the shop has experienced problems with exploding Apple devices. SHARE A still from the YouTube video of the incident. 
"We have had iPhone batteries explode before," says Mr Owen. 
"It was an iPhone 5 battery about three years ago. When they blow, they smoke like that because the two chemicals in the battery mix. It sets off a toxic green haze. It set the whole bin on fire. After that we bought fire equipment [used in the most recent video]." SHARE A still from the YouTube video of the incident. Photo: YouTube 
"He bought me a case of beer," says Mr Owen about the customer. 
"In regional Australia that's what you do." 
A staff member then douses the smouldering device with a fire extinguisher. 
The video follows an incident in which a pair of headphones exploded while being worn on a flight from Beijing to Melbourne . 
Two hours into the flight, a female passenger woke to a loud explosion and felt burning on her face, leaving her with a burnt face, hand and singed hair. 
The incident caused The Australian Transport Safety Bureau to issue an official warning about using batteries on flights. 
The recent cases of battery issues from this week follow the well-publicised disaster for Samsung in September when its newly released Note7 began exploding due to battery issues. 
It caused a global recall of the product by the company, costing it an estimated US$5.3 billion in operating profit. 
Apple has largely avoided similar PR disasters with their iPhone releases, bar isolated incidents such as when a Sydney cyclist claimed to be severely burnt last year when his Apple iPhone exploded after a minor fall. 
Apple was contacted for comment. Advertisement
